<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 294]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS

9709/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
May/June 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 217, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
In a survey of 200 randomly chosen students from a certain college, \(23\%\) of the students said that they owned a car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate \(93\%\) confidence interval for the proportion of students from the college who own a car.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 562, 92]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(W\) has a Poisson distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 554, 123]]<|/det|>
State the relationship between \(\operatorname {E}(W)\) and \(\operatorname {Var}(W)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 216, 146, 234]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 216, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathsf{B}(n, p)\). Jyothi wishes to use a Poisson distribution as an approximate distribution for \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 262, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
Use the formulae for \(\operatorname {E}(X)\) and \(\operatorname {Var}(X)\) to explain why it is necessary for \(p\) to be close to 0 for this to be a reasonable approximation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 276, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 488, 144, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 488, 920, 522]]<|/det|>
Given that \(Y\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}(20 000, 0.000 07)\), use a Poisson distribution to calculate an estimate of \(\mathrm{P}(Y > 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 502, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
The masses, in kilograms, of newborn babies in country \(A\) are represented by the random variable \(X\), with mean \(\mu\) and variance \(\sigma^2\). The masses of a random sample of 500 newborn babies in this country were found and the results are summarised below.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[329, 131, 668, 149]]<|/det|>
\[n = 500\qquad \Sigma x = 1625\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 5663.5\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 170, 146, 188]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 168, 490, 187]]<|/det|>
Calculate unbiased estimates of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A researcher wishes to test whether the mean mass of newborn babies in a neighbouring country, \(B\), is different from that in country \(A\). He chooses a random sample of 60 newborn babies in country \(B\) and finds that their sample mean mass is \(2.95 \mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
Assume that your unbiased estimates in part (a) are the correct values for \(\mu\) and \(\sigma^2\). Assume also that the variance of the masses of newborn babies in country \(B\) is the same as in country \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 183, 146, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 183, 526, 201]]<|/det|>
Carry out the test at the \(1\%\) significance level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 811, 92]]<|/det|>
The number, \(X\), of books received at a charity shop has a constant mean of 5.1 per day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 782, 123]]<|/det|>
State, in context, one condition for \(X\) to be modelled by a Poisson distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 248, 620, 267]]<|/det|>
Assume now that \(X\) can be modelled by a Poisson distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 280, 146, 298]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 280, 740, 298]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that exactly 10 books are received in a 3-day period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 280, 920, 298]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 457, 144, 475]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 457, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find the probability that more than 180 books are received in a 30-day period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 470, 920, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The number of DVDs received at the same shop is modelled by an independent Poisson distribution with mean 2.5 per day.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 148, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 120, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the total number of books and DVDs that are received at the shop in 1 day is more than 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Two random variables \(X\) and \(Y\) have the independent distributions \(\mathrm{N}(7, 3)\) and \(\mathrm{N}(6, 2)\) respectively. A random value of each variable is taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 650, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the two values differ by more than 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Each candidate's overall score in a science test is calculated as follows. The mark for theory is denoted by \(T\), the mark for practical is denoted by \(P\), and the overall score is given by \(T + 1.5P\). The variables \(T\) and \(P\) are assumed to be independent with distributions \(\mathrm{N}(62, 158)\) and \(\mathrm{N}(42, 108)\) respectively. You should assume that no continuity corrections are needed when using these distributions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[166, 161, 196, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 160, 724, 180]]<|/det|>
A pass is awarded to candidates whose overall score is at least 90.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 185, 547, 203]]<|/det|>
Find the proportion of candidates who pass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 186, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[198, 717, 774, 734]]<|/det|>
Comment on the assumption that the variables \(T\) and \(P\) are independent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 718, 920, 735]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 755, 920, 772]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 797, 920, 814]]<|/det|>

<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 881, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
<form>......

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
When a child completes an online exercise called a Mathlit, they might be awarded a medal. The publishers claim that the probability that a randomly chosen child who completes a Mathlit will be awarded a medal is \(\frac{1}{3}\). Asha wishes to test this claim. She decides that if she is awarded no medals while completing 10 Mathlits, she will conclude that the true probability is less than \(\frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 157, 146, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 156, 695, 175]]<|/det|>
Use a binomial distribution to find the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 157, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 465, 621, 485]]<|/det|>
The true probability of being awarded a medal is denoted by \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 496, 148, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 496, 744, 515]]<|/det|>
Given that the probability of a Type II error is 0.8926, find the value of \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 497, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 88, 717, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 231, 920, 284]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of the probability density function, g, of a random variable \(W\) which takes values between 0 and \(a\) only, where \(a > 0\). Between these two values the graph is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 294, 574, 314]]<|/det|>
Given that the median of \(W\) is 1, find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 295, 920, 314]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
